The velocity gradient tensor for homogeneous, isotropic turbulence (HIT), with explicit consideration of local and non-local effects using a Schur decomposition

Christopher J. Keylock 1Sheffield Fluid Mechanics Group and Department of Civil and Structural Engineering, University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, UK
Abstract

A Schur decomposition of the velocity gradient tensor (VGT) for homogeneous, isotropic turbulence (HIT) is undertaken and its physical consequences examined. This decomposition permits the normal parts of the tensor (represented by the eigenvalues) to be separated explicitly from the non-normal effects. Given the restricted Euler approximation to the VGT dynamics is written in terms of the isotropic part of the pressure Hessian and the invariants of the characteristic equation of the VGT (in turn expressed in terms of the eigenvalues), the non-normal terms are related to the non-local aspects of the dynamics and the anisotropic part of the pressure Hessian. Using a direct numerical simulation of HIT, we show that the norm of the non-normal part of the tensor is of a similar order to the normal part, highlighting the importance of non-local effects. In fact, beneath the discriminant function in a Qâˆ’RQR\mbox{Q}-\mbox{R} plot, all enstrophy arises from the non-normal term, meaning that vorticity and intermediate strain eigenvector alignment in this region is an immediate consequence of non-normality. A non-normal term appears in the expressions for both enstrophy and total strain and cancels when calculating the second invariant of the VGT, while the self-amplification of non-normality and the normal straining of non-normality appear in the strain production and enstrophy production equations and cancel when calculating the third invariant. However, these terms are significant for understanding the full VGT dynamics, explaining how flow structures evolve to a disc-like state despite the strain eigenvalues sometimes indicating opposite (rod-like) behaviour, as well as explaining vorticity and strain alignments in HIT.

I Introduction

I.1 Brief overview

This paper is concerned with properties of the velocity gradient tensor (VGT) for incompressible, homogeneous, isotropic turbulence (HIT). This is a classical topic in turbulence fluid mechanics as HIT is the testing ground for a great deal of turbulence theory. A recent review paper by Meneveau (2011) provides a great deal of information on the properties of the VGT and serves as both a basis and a point of departure for this study. The key difference between this study and previous work concerns the form of decomposition of the tensor that underpins the analysis. Conventional studies employ the clearly physically interpretable Hermitian/skew-Hermitian decomposition into strain, ğ–²ğ–²\mathsf{S}, and rotation, Î©sans-serif-Î©\mathsf{\Omega}, components, with the latter often then modified to a vorticity vector. However, the eigenvalues are also important for delimiting different topological states of the tensor, and therefore there is some history to studying the invariants of the characteristic equation for the VGT. Our approach is to prioritize the eigenvalue-based approach and to then deploy a subsequent Hermitian/skew-Hermitian decomposition. However, the first thing we note is that, just examining the eigenvalues is insufficient. While the Hermitian/skew-Hermitian decomposition gives an additive decomposition of the velocity gradient tensor, ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}:

ğ– =ğ–²+Î©,ğ– ğ–²sans-serif-Î©\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{S}+\mathsf{\Omega}, (1)

to form the equivalent with an eigenvalue-based approach, we need a decomposition of the tensor into a normal tensor, ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B}, (characterized by the eigenvalues) and a non-normal part, ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}, (characterizing the local torques acting on the tensor resulting from tensor asymmetries). Hence, we may write an alternative to (1) as

ğ– =ğ–¡+ğ–¢.ğ– ğ–¡ğ–¢\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{B}+\mathsf{C}. (2)

The tool from matrix algebra we use to accomplish this is the Schur transform (Schur, 1909).

Having commenced our analysis of ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} from this starting point, we can then use the Hermitian/skew-Hermitian decompositions of ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B} and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C} to elucidate the relative importance of strain and rotation for both the normal and non-normal parts of the tensor. We use this framework to re-interrogate and shed further light on a number of properties of the VGT.

The well-known Qâˆ’RQR\mbox{Q}-\mbox{R} diagram (QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} in our notation) is shown for homogeneous, isotropic turbulence (HIT) at a Taylor Reynolds number of 433 in Fig. 1, with the discriminant function, Î”LsubscriptÎ”ğ¿\Delta_{L} as a solid line and the six regions that are delimited throughout this study also labelled. The features of this diagram are well-known and of particular prominence is the Vieillefosse tail (Vieillefosse, 1984) that forms a â€˜ridgeâ€™ to the joint distribution function on the positive RAsubscriptğ‘…ğ´R_{A} side. The degree of mass along the tail, close to the origin and in the opposite, (Q>0,R>0formulae-sequenceQ0R0\mbox{Q}>0,\mbox{R}>0), quadrant can be shown to be statistically significant features of HIT both with respect to Gaussian, random tensors (Tsinober, 2001) and random tensors constrained to local properties (Keylock, 2017). It was shown by Cantwell that the restricted Euler equations that consider the dynamics of the velocity gradient tensor only in terms of QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A} and RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A} (see below) have two possible solutions (Cantwell, 1992):

  • â€¢

    Given the timescale, t0=1/|QA0|subscriptğ‘¡01superscriptsubscriptQğ´0t_{0}=1/\sqrt{|\mbox{Q}_{A}^{0}|}, for QA0=0,RA<0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptQğ´00subscriptRğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}^{0}=0,\mbox{R}_{A}<0 the solutions evolve to the fixed point, QA=RA=0subscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}=\mbox{R}_{A}=0;

  • â€¢

    For any other initial conditions the solution evolves towards the Vieillefosse tail, defined as the bottom right quadrant of Fig. 1 along the line Î”L=0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}=0.

That the majority of points lie close to the origin, or along the Vieillefosse tail, highlights the importance of the restricted Euler approximation. However, it is clearly necessary to go beyond this approach to derive a workable model for the velocity gradient tensor dynamics that includes terms that prevent the mass of the distribution function over-accumulating at the extreme of the Vieillefosse tail. There have been a number of papers that have proposed models for this behavior and these are discussed briefly below. However, a contribution to this area is not the intent of this study, which focuses instead on refining understanding of terms associated with the evolution of the VGT.

Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss summarizes how the velocity gradient tensors for HIT extracted from the Johns Hopkins database used to populate Fig. 1 are distributed over the six regions of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram and the four feasible states for enstrophy production and strain production based on their signs. What is very clear is that the two most frequently occupied regions in terms of their relative occupany, regions 2 and 6, with opposite signs for QAsubscriptğ‘„ğ´Q_{A} and RAsubscriptğ‘…ğ´R_{A}, are both dominated by positive strain production and enstrophy production. Clearly the relative magnitudes of these terms differ significantly in these two cases to establish the change in sign for RAsubscriptğ‘…ğ´R_{A}. The only region where tensors with negative values for both enstophy production and strain production are more likely than tensors with both terms positive is region 1. The opposite region to this (region 4) has a nearly equal probability of the two strain/enstrophy production states, while in the regions adjacent to, but above, the discriminant function (regions 3 and 5) it is seen that the physically feasible combination with different signs for the two production terms is nearly as likely as the case where both are positive. Hence, these latter two regions exhibit intermediate characteristics compared to regions 2 and 4, and 1 and 6, respectively.

I.3 Models for the velocity gradient tensor

The restricted Euler model for the velocity gradient tensor already discussed (Cantwell, 1992) has been followed by a number of studies that have sought to improve the physical representation of the Lagrangian dynamics of the velocity gradient tensor (Girimaji and Pope, 1990; Martin etÂ al, 1998; Chevillard etÂ al, 2008; Wilczek and Meneveau, 2014; Johnson and Meneveau, 2016). These studies have followed a stochastic approach where the unclosed terms in the Lagrangian evolution equation (the deviatoric part of the pressure Hessian and the viscous term) are split into fluctuations that are modelled as Gaussian white noise, and mean quantities conditioned on the velocity gradient tensor itself. Such models result in behaviour in QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} space that is a much better representation of the true PDF than seen in the restricted Euler formalism (see Fig. 6 of Johnson and Meneveau (2016) by way of example).

More related to the theme of this paper is the formulation of the full set of coupled ODEs that describe the Lagrangian evolution of ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} (Martin etÂ al, 1998; Nomura and Post, 1998). Such an approach also benefits from a decomposition of the presure Hessian, ğ–§ğ–§\mathsf{H}, in (4) into isotropic and deviatoric parts (Ohkitani and Kishiba, 1995):

ğ–§iâ€‹sâ€‹osuperscriptğ–§ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘œ\displaystyle\mathsf{H}^{iso} =âˆ’23â€‹QAâ€‹ğ–¨â‰¡13â€‹trâ€‹(ğ–§)â€‹ğ–¨,absent23subscriptQğ´ğ–¨13trğ–§ğ–¨\displaystyle=-\frac{2}{3}\mbox{Q}_{A}\mathsf{I}\equiv\frac{1}{3}\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{H})\mathsf{I}, (13)

where ğ–¨ğ–¨\mathsf{I} is the 3Ã—3333\times 3 identity matrix and the substitution of ğ–°Asubscriptğ–°ğ´\mathsf{Q}_{A} for the trace of the Hessian comes from the Poisson equation for the pressure.

The isotropic term acts to preserve the volume of the fluid element without directional preference, and the deviatoric term includes all the non-local effects from the surrounding flow (hence, requiring an integration over the whole flow). Thus, where Î”L>0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}>0 and enstrophy dominates total strain, the isotropic part acts to reduce the enstrophy growth rate, so that amplification is either due to stretching, i.e. the enstrophy production trâ€‹(Î©A2â€‹ğ–²A)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğ´2subscriptğ–²ğ´\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{A}), or the action of ğ–§dâ€‹eâ€‹vsuperscriptğ–§ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘£\mathsf{H}^{dev}.

We revisit the component terms in these equations in the next sections, where they are re-cast and studied from the perspective of the formulation developed in this paper. First, however, we develop our alternate approach to tensorial decomposition and examine some of its implications and consequences.

II A formulation of velocity gradient tensor analysis resolving normal and non-normal effects explicitly

II.1 Tensor non-normality and the Schur transform

The primary innovation in this study is to undertake an additive decomposition of the velocity gradient tensor, ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}, into normal, ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B}, and non-normal, ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}, components before any subsequent decomposition into rotation or straining aspects. This permits us to unpack a number of phenomena commonly lumped together and thereby clarify the behaviour of the tensor. If ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} is normal, then

ğ– ğ– âˆ—=ğ– âˆ—â€‹ğ– .superscriptğ– ğ– superscriptğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}\mathsf{A}^{*}=\mathsf{A}^{*}\mathsf{A}. (19)

The eigenvalue decomposition is given by

ğ–«â€‹Î›â€‹ğ–«âˆ’1=ğ– ,ğ–«sans-serif-Î›superscriptğ–«1ğ– \mathsf{L}\mathsf{\Lambda}\mathsf{L}^{-1}=\mathsf{A}, (20)

where ğ–«ğ–«\mathsf{L} contains the eigenvectors and Î›sans-serif-Î›\mathsf{\Lambda} is a diagonal matrix of eigenvalues (Î›1,1=Î»1subscriptÎ›11subscriptğœ†1\Lambda_{1,1}=\lambda_{1}). We now state the Schur transform (Schur, 1909):

ğ–´ğ–³ğ–´âˆ—=ğ– ,superscriptğ–´ğ–³ğ–´ğ– \mathsf{U}\mathsf{T}\mathsf{U}^{*}=\mathsf{A}, (21)

where ğ–´ğ–´\mathsf{U} is unitary and ğ–³=Î›+ğ–­ğ–³sans-serif-Î›ğ–­\mathsf{T}=\mathsf{\Lambda}+\mathsf{N}, with ğ–­ğ–­\mathsf{N} an upper triangular tensor. We note that because the Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i} may contain a conjugate pair (where Î”L>0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}>0), to ensure ğ–­ğ–­\mathsf{N} is upper triangular rather than quasi-upper triangular, a complex Schur decomposition is used throughout this study (Golub and van Loan, 2013). The appendix reviews the distinction between the complex and real forms for the decomposition.

Note that the Schur transform contains a stronger constraint than the eigen decomposition on the form of the rotation matrix. Because ğ–´ğ–´\mathsf{U} is unitary, ğ–´ğ–´âˆ—=ğ–¨superscriptğ–´ğ–´ğ–¨\mathsf{U}\mathsf{U}^{*}=\mathsf{I}, where ğ–¨ğ–¨\mathsf{I} is the identity matrix, and this means that ğ–´ğ–´âˆ’1=ğ–¨superscriptğ–´ğ–´1ğ–¨\mathsf{U}\mathsf{U}^{-1}=\mathsf{I} as well. For the eigen decomposition, while ğ–«ğ–«âˆ’1=ğ–¨superscriptğ–«ğ–«1ğ–¨\mathsf{L}\mathsf{L}^{-1}=\mathsf{I}, ğ–«ğ–«âˆ—=ğ–¨superscriptğ–«ğ–«ğ–¨\mathsf{L}\mathsf{L}^{*}=\mathsf{I} is only true when ğ–³=Î›ğ–³sans-serif-Î›\mathsf{T}=\mathsf{\Lambda}, i.e. ğ–­=ğ–®ğ–­ğ–®\mathsf{N}=\mathsf{O} and, therefore, ğ–«=ğ–´ğ–«ğ–´\mathsf{L}=\mathsf{U}. From (20) and (21), when ğ–­ğ–­\mathsf{N} is a zero tensor, ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} is normal and described thoroughly by its eigenvalues. It therefore follows that ğ– ğ– âˆ—â‰ ğ– âˆ—â€‹ğ– superscriptğ– ğ– superscriptğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}\mathsf{A}^{*}\neq\mathsf{A}^{*}\mathsf{A} and â€–ğ–­â€–>0normğ–­0||\mathsf{N}||>0 are both measures of non-normality and there are a number of papers that give bounds for â€–ğ–­â€–normğ–­||\mathsf{N}|| given â€–ğ– ğ– âˆ—âˆ’ğ– âˆ—â€‹ğ– â€–normsuperscriptğ– ğ– superscriptğ– ğ– ||\mathsf{A}\mathsf{A}^{*}-\mathsf{A}^{*}\mathsf{A}|| (Henrici, 1962; Eberlein, 1965; Lee, 1995). Thus, some â€˜residualâ€™ dynamics exist independent of the eigenvalues of ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} and the advantage of the Schur decomposition is that it moves these effects out of the eigenvectors (orientations) and into a tensor ğ–­ğ–­\mathsf{N} that, with the eigenvalues, contributes to ğ–³ğ–³\mathsf{T}.

II.2 Normal and non-normal velocity gradient tensors and properties of the second invariant of the velocity gradient tensor

Returning to our alternative additive decomposition postulated in (2), we may now write that:

ğ–¡ğ–¡\displaystyle\mathsf{B} =\displaystyle= ğ–´â€‹Î›â€‹ğ–´âˆ—ğ–´sans-serif-Î›superscriptğ–´\displaystyle\mathsf{U}\mathsf{\Lambda}\mathsf{U}^{*} (22)
ğ–¢ğ–¢\displaystyle\mathsf{C} =\displaystyle= ğ–´ğ–­ğ–´âˆ—,superscriptğ–´ğ–­ğ–´\displaystyle\mathsf{U}\mathsf{N}\mathsf{U}^{*}, (23)

and this is the key conceptual innovation in this paper. Thus, ğ– =ğ–¡+ğ–¢ğ– ğ–¡ğ–¢\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{B}+\mathsf{C} provides an explicit means to separate the normal and non-normal contributions to the dynamics. That is, we have an additive decomposition into a tensor, ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B} containing the dynamics driven by the eigenvalues, which from the restricted Euler formulation are preferentially associated with the local dynamics, and a tensor, ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C} that contains dynamics that are a result of asymmetric structure in the VGT induced by non-local effects.

Taking the rotation and strain tensors for ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B} and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}, we have

ğ–¡ğ–¡\displaystyle\mathsf{B} =ğ–²B+Î©Babsentsubscriptğ–²ğµsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ\displaystyle=\mathsf{S}_{B}+\mathsf{\Omega}_{B} (24)

II.3 Some physical aspects of this decomposition

From the above section we see that, in terms of the first two, autonomous ODEs for the VGT dynamics (16,17), we may directly substitute expressions written for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} with those for ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B}. This is physically intuitive because the restricted Euler formulation is a local and inviscid model involving the isotropic part of the pressure Hessian only. Studying the component terms of the second and third invariants when â€–ğ–¢â€–â‰ 0normğ–¢0||\mathsf{C}||\neq 0 introduces non-local effects into consideration.

A further important aspect of our approach is that the discriminant, Î”LsubscriptÎ”ğ¿\Delta_{L} has explicit physical consequences in the analysis of rotation, which is not the case when one studies â€–ğ–²Aâ€–normsubscriptğ–²ğ´||\mathsf{S}_{A}|| and â€–Î©Aâ€–normsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğ´||\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}||. Thus, while the discriminant function partitioning real eigenvalue regions from a conjugate pair and closed streamlines is super-imposed on Fig. 1, the total strain and enstrophy for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} are defined continuously over the ğ–°Asubscriptğ–°ğ´\mathsf{Q}_{A} axis (although, of course, their relative magnitudes change). The advantage of our approach is that because ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B} is an eigenvalue-based tensor, Î”L=0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}=0 demarcates a change in physical behaviour. Mathematically, this arises because the eigenvalues for ğ–²Bsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mathsf{S}_{B} and Î©Bsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ\mathsf{\Omega}_{B} are the real and imaginary parts of the eigenvalues for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}. Hence, where Î”L<0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}<0 there is no imaginary part and we have â€–Î©Bâ€–=0normsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ0||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||=0, i.e. there is no rotation in the normal part of the tensor. Therefore, QB=âˆ’12â€‹â€–ğ–²Bâ€–2subscriptQğµ12superscriptnormsubscriptğ–²ğµ2\mbox{Q}_{B}=-\frac{1}{2}||\mathsf{S}_{B}||^{2} and all enstrophy comes from ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}, a contribution to QBsubscriptQğµ\mbox{Q}_{B} that is equal to the strain contribution from ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}. As a consequence of â€–Î©Bâ€–=0normsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ0||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||=0, trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)=0trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ2subscriptğ–²ğµ0\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B})=0 and the eigenvalues. for RBsubscriptRğµ\mbox{R}_{B} and RB(S)subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğµ\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B} are identical. Hence, the third invariant also has a simple expression beneath the discriminant function in this case: RAâ‰¡RB=RB(S)subscriptRğ´subscriptRğµsubscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğµ\mbox{R}_{A}\equiv\mbox{R}_{B}=\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B}.

Above the discriminant function, while we can no longer equate the values for the third invariant of ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} with those for RB(S)subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğµ\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B}, we can state that sgnâ€‹(RB(S))=sgnâ€‹(RB)sgnsubscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğµsgnsubscriptRğµ\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B})=\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{B}). From the eigenvalue structure, it follows that

Therefore, the basic nature of the normal contributions to strain production and enstrophy production are known from inspection of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram and observed departures from such relations for trâ€‹(Î©A2â€‹ğ–²A)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğ´2subscriptğ–²ğ´\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{A}) and âˆ’detâ€‹(ğ–²A)detsubscriptğ–²ğ´-\mbox{det}(\mathsf{S}_{A}), as identified in Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss, are a consequence of the over-riding influence of the non-normal terms or those representing the interaction between normal and non-normal effects.

II.7 The second strain eigenvalue and its Lund and Rogers normalization

One property of HIT that was observed in the early simulations was a strong preference for a positive second eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor (Kerr, 1985; Ashurst etÂ al, 1987). This may be inferred from the shape of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram in Fig. 1 and, in particular, the values in Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss that indicate a preference for positive strain production and, thus, two positive eigenvalues. Topologically, this means that flow packets are more prone to evolve to disc-like features than rod-like features.

The Lund and Rogers normalization of the second eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor is given by (Lund and Rogers, 1994):

eA(Lâ€‹R)=3â€‹6â€‹RA(S)(âˆ’2â€‹QA(S))32,subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´36subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´superscript2subscriptsuperscriptQğ‘†ğ´32e^{(LR)}_{A}=\frac{3\sqrt{6}\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}}{\left(-2\mbox{Q}^{(S)}_{A}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}, (44)

which is bounded to âˆ’1â‰¤eA(Lâ€‹R)â‰¤11subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1-1\leq e^{(LR)}_{A}\leq 1. Similar relative measures for the second strain eigenvalue for ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B} and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C} then follow. However, we noted in (37) that our formulation for RA(S)subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A} also contains an interaction term: RA(S)=RB(S)+RC(S)+trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)superscriptsubscriptRğ´ğ‘†subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğµsubscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ¶trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğ¶2subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{R}_{A}^{(S)}=\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B}+\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{C}+\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B}). Hence, we can also study

eB|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğµğ´\displaystyle e^{(LR)}_{B|A} =3â€‹6â€‹RB(S)(âˆ’2â€‹QA(S))32absent36subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğµsuperscript2subscriptsuperscriptQğ‘†ğ´32\displaystyle=\frac{3\sqrt{6}\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{B}}{\left(-2\mbox{Q}^{(S)}_{A}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}} (45)
eC|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´\displaystyle e^{(LR)}_{C|A} =3â€‹6â€‹RC(S)(âˆ’2â€‹QA(S))32absent36subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ¶superscript2subscriptsuperscriptQğ‘†ğ´32\displaystyle=\frac{3\sqrt{6}\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{C}}{\left(-2\mbox{Q}^{(S)}_{A}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}} (46)

II.8 Alignment properties of the vorticity vector and the strain eigenvectors

An important and surprising early result in the study of the velocity gradient tensor was the preferred alignment between the vorticity vector, ğAsubscriptğğ´\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A} and the eigenvector for the intermediate eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor (Kerr, 1985; Ashurst etÂ al, 1987; Jimenez, 1992). Our decomposition gives vorticity vectors for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}, ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B}, and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}, respectively, as well as nine possible strain eigenvectors. Thus we introduce the notation that with eiAsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ´e_{i}^{A} indicating an eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}, ordered from most positive to most negative, and ğiAsubscriptsuperscriptğğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{A}_{i} its corresponding eigenvector, we can define, as an example:

Î¸iA,C=cosâ¡(ğA,ğiC),subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ¶ğ‘–subscriptğğ´subscriptsuperscriptğğ¶ğ‘–\theta^{A,C}_{i}=\cos(\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A},\mathbf{e}^{C}_{i}), (48)

as the angle between the vorticity vector for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} and the ith eigenvector for ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}.

One aspect of our decomposition is that because ğ–²A=ğ–²B+ğ–²Csubscriptğ–²ğ´subscriptğ–²ğµsubscriptğ–²ğ¶\mathsf{S}_{A}=\mathsf{S}_{B}+\mathsf{S}_{C}, we can examine the alignment between ğiAsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘–ğ´\mathbf{e}_{i}^{A}, and ğjBsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘—ğµ\mathbf{e}_{j}^{B} or ğkCsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘˜ğ¶\mathbf{e}_{k}^{C}. For example,

Ï•i,jA,B=cosâ¡(ğiA,ğjB).superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ´ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘–ğ´superscriptsubscriptğğ‘—ğµ\phi_{i,j}^{A,B}=\cos(\mathbf{e}_{i}^{A},\mathbf{e}_{j}^{B}). (49)

Note that the eigenvalues for ğ–²Bsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mathsf{S}_{B} are always equal to the real part of the eigenvalues for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}. Hence, as described in section II.3, when above the discriminant function, we will always have a pair of equal eigenvalues, meaning that the second eigenvalue for ğ–²Bsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mathsf{S}_{B} is not properly defined in regions 1, 2, 3, and 5.

Finally, we may also consider vorticity vector alignments, such as

Î¾A,B=cosâ¡(ğA,ğB).superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğµsuperscriptğğ´superscriptğğµ\xi^{A,B}=\cos(\boldsymbol{\omega}^{A},\boldsymbol{\omega}^{B}). (50)

Because the eigenvalues for ğBsubscriptğğµ\boldsymbol{\omega}_{B} are the imaginary part of the eigenvalues for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}, beneath the discriminant function, in regions 4 and 6, ğA=ğCsubscriptğğ´subscriptğğ¶\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A}=\boldsymbol{\omega}_{C} and Î¾A,C=1superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶1\xi^{A,C}=1 with Î¾A,Bsuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğµ\xi^{A,B} and Î¾B,Csuperscriptğœ‰ğµğ¶\xi^{B,C} undefined.

III The Numerical Simulation

This study makes use of velocity gradient tensors extracted from the Johns Hopkins Turbulence Database numerical simulation of forced isotropic turbulence at a Taylor Reynolds number of 433 (Li etÂ al, 2008) as described by Wan etÂ al (2016). The direct numerical simulation is undertaken on a 10243superscript102431024^{3} grid using a pseudo-spectral method. The energy is injected to maintain the total energy in the Fourier modes, and also retaining a wave number magnitude less than or equal to 2 in each mode. The basic properties of the simulation are summarized in Table 3 and a number of other studies have made use of this resource for studying turbulence physics (Wan etÂ al, 2010; Lawson and Dawson, 2015) or for the testing of data post-processing algorithms (Higham etÂ al, 2016).

IV Results: The role of non-normality

IV.1 The importance of non-normal effects

Given our decomposition, ğ– =ğ–¡+ğ–¢ğ– ğ–¡ğ–¢\mathsf{A}=\mathsf{B}+\mathsf{C}, the first thing to establish is the relative importance of the normal and non-normal tensors; clearly if ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C} is small then it is legitimate to approximate the behaviour of ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} with eigenvalue-based formulations. To evaluate this aspect of the behaviour of our decomposition we can define

ÎºB,Csubscriptğœ…ğµğ¶\displaystyle\kappa_{B,C} =â€–ğ–¡â€–âˆ’â€–ğ–¢â€–â€–ğ–¡â€–+â€–ğ–¢â€–,absentnormğ–¡normğ–¢normğ–¡normğ–¢\displaystyle=\frac{||\mathsf{B}||-||\mathsf{C}||}{||\mathsf{B}||+||\mathsf{C}||}, (51)

as a normalized measure of the magnitude of the two tensors. This is shown in Fig. 2 and it is clear from the upper panel that the overall mode for the distribution is slightly negative, with a median close to ÎºB,C=0subscriptğœ…ğµğ¶0\kappa_{B,C}=0. Hence, the non-normality is as important to the tensor as the part explained by the eigenvalues. Thus, in HIT, asymmetrical forcings on the tensor as a consequence of non-local effects are an important part of the flow dynamics. When the results in Fig. 2 are partitioned by the six regions of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram, we see that for each pair of diagrams for a given QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A} state, it is the left-hand variant, with RA<0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}<0, where there is a greater contribution from â€–ğ–¢â€–normğ–¢||\mathsf{C}||.

Region 3 is where ÎºB,Csubscriptğœ…ğµğ¶\kappa_{B,C} is most strongly negative and region 6 is where ÎºB,Csubscriptğœ…ğµğ¶\kappa_{B,C} is most positive. This latter result is all the more impressive because for Î”L<0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}<0 (regions 4 and 6), â€–Î©Bâ€–=0normsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ0||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||=0, meaning that in the majority of instances, â€–ğ–²Bâ€–>â€–ğ–²Câ€–+â€–Î©Câ€–normsubscriptğ–²ğµnormsubscriptğ–²ğ¶normsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğ¶||\mathsf{S}_{B}||>||\mathsf{S}_{C}||+||\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}||, or â€–ğ–²Bâ€–>2â€‹â€–ğ–²Câ€–normsubscriptğ–²ğµ2normsubscriptğ–²ğ¶||\mathsf{S}_{B}||>2||\mathsf{S}_{C}||. Thus, an eigenvalue-based description of the flow is particularly effective near the Vieillefosse tail, which is consistent with this being an attractor for the dynamics of the restricted Euler (eigenvalue-based) set of equations for the dynamics of the VGT (Cantwell, 1992).

IV.2 The second invariant and non-normality

From (28), we may examine the components of the second invariant with respect to non-normality

ÎºQ(Î©)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©\displaystyle\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)} =â€–Î©Bâ€–âˆ’â€–ğ–²Câ€–â€–Î©Bâ€–+â€–ğ–²Câ€–absentnormsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµnormsubscriptğ–²ğ¶normsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµnormsubscriptğ–²ğ¶\displaystyle=\frac{||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||-||\mathsf{S}_{C}||}{||\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}||+||\mathsf{S}_{C}||} (52)
ÎºQ(S)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†\displaystyle\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} =â€–ğ–²Bâ€–âˆ’â€–ğ–²Câ€–â€–ğ–²Bâ€–+â€–ğ–²Câ€–.absentnormsubscriptğ–²ğµnormsubscriptğ–²ğ¶normsubscriptğ–²ğµnormsubscriptğ–²ğ¶\displaystyle=\frac{||\mathsf{S}_{B}||-||\mathsf{S}_{C}||}{||\mathsf{S}_{B}||+||\mathsf{S}_{C}||}. (53)

Beneath the discriminant function, ÎºQ(Î©)=âˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©1\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}=-1 by definition and such results are not shown in the panels for regions (4) and (6) in Fig. 3. Their contribution to the overall distribution function for ÎºQ(Î©)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)} is shown in the top panel, which has a log-scale because of the dominance of the -1 limit. The second panel is on a linear scale and the results for ÎºQ(Î©)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)} are shown as a dotted line and exclude the values at -1, providing a better means to evaluate the overall shape of the distribution.

While an increase in the mean values for ÎºQ(Î©)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)} and decrease for ÎºQ(S)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} with QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A} is very distinct, the differences as a function of the sign of RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A} are more obvious than in Fig. 2. For example, while we anticipate a difference between regions 4 and 6 in their values for ÎºQ(S)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} from the discussion of Fig. 2, their respective modes of 0.16 and 0.28 indicate this very clearly. In regions 3 and 5, where Î”L>0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}>0 and QA<0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}<0, we have a positive mode for region 5 at ÎºQ(S)=0.07superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0.07\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}=0.07 and a mode of ÎºQ(S)=âˆ’0.12superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0.12\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}=-0.12 for region 3. Furthermore, the probability of ÎºQ(Î©)<âˆ’0.995superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©0.995\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}<-0.995 is much higher in region 5 at p=0.018ğ‘0.018p=0.018 (it is the distributionâ€™s mode) than in region 3 (p=0.003ğ‘0.003p=0.003). This highlights the extent to which the Vieillefosse tail is an attractor for the dynamics as there is a concentration of values lying very close to Î”L=0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}=0 in region 5, but not region 3.

Where QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, we see that the mode in region 1 for ÎºQ(Î©)=0.18superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©0.18\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}=0.18 is more positive than for region 2 (ÎºQ(Î©)=0.12superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©0.12\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}=0.12), and there is also a stronger tendency for ÎºQ(S)â†’âˆ’1â†’superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†1\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}\to-1. Hence, a simplified and approximate view of the right-hand side of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram is that ÎºQ(S)=âˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†1\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}=-1 for QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 and ÎºQ(Î©)=âˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„Î©1\kappa_{Q}^{(\Omega)}=-1 for QA<0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}<0. In both regions 1 and 2 there are a similar proportion of positive ÎºQ(S)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} occurrences (8.5% and 7.1%, respectively). In such cases the degree of compression or extension due to ğ–²Bsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mathsf{S}_{B} is greater than from the non-normal part, on average, implying there is a strong and coherent motion orthogonal to the plane of rotation driven by normal straining. This particular hypothesis is considered in Section VI.5 where we summarize the various alignment properties of the tensor.

IV.3 The third invariant and non-normality

The components of the third invariant are listed and interpreted in Table LABEL:table.terms. In a similar fashion to the non-normal contribution cancelling when evaluating the second invariant because RA=RBsubscriptRğ´subscriptRğµ\mbox{R}_{A}=\mbox{R}_{B}, the non-normal and interaction terms appear in a similar fashion in both the strain production (37) and enstrophy production (38) equations. Thus, in this section, we determine the relative significance of non-normal production, RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} and interaction production, trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğ¶2subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{C}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B}) relative to the two normal terms: normal strain production, RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}, and normal enstrophy production, trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ2subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B}).

First, we examine the extent to which the sum of the component terms, i.e. RASsubscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´\mbox{R}^{S}_{A} and trâ€‹(Î©A2â€‹ğ–²A)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğ´2subscriptğ–²ğ´\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{A}) equates to the sum of the absolute values for each term as a means to assess the extent to which component terms are opposite in sign to RA(S)subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A} and trâ€‹(Î©A2â€‹ğ–²A)trsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğ´2subscriptğ–²ğ´\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}_{A}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{A}):

[RA(S)]âˆ—superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´\displaystyle[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*} =RA(S)|RB(S)|+|RC(S)|+|trâ€‹(ğ–²C2â€‹ğ–²B)|absentsubscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†trsuperscriptsubscriptğ–²ğ¶2subscriptğ–²ğµ\displaystyle=\frac{\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}}{|\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}|+|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|+|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{S}_{C}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B})|} (54)
[trâ€‹(Î©A2â€‹SA)]âˆ—superscriptdelimited-[]trsubscriptsuperscriptÎ©2ğ´subscriptğ‘†ğ´\displaystyle[\mbox{tr}(\Omega^{2}_{A}{S}_{A})]^{*} =trâ€‹(Î©A2â€‹SA)|trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹SB)|+|RC(S)|+|trâ€‹(ğ–²C2â€‹ğ–²B)|absenttrsubscriptsuperscriptÎ©2ğ´subscriptğ‘†ğ´trsubscriptsuperscriptÎ©2ğµsubscriptğ‘†ğµsuperscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†trsuperscriptsubscriptğ–²ğ¶2subscriptğ–²ğµ\displaystyle=\frac{\mbox{tr}(\Omega^{2}_{A}{S}_{A})}{|\mbox{tr}(\Omega^{2}_{B}{S}_{B})|+|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|+|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{S}_{C}^{2}\mathsf{S}_{B})|} (55)

Figure 4 shows the values for [RA(S)]âˆ—superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*} as a function of the region of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptğ‘„ğ´subscriptğ‘…ğ´Q_{A}-R_{A} diagram and the signs of RA(S)subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A} and for trâ€‹(Î©A2â€‹SA)trsubscriptsuperscriptÎ©2ğ´subscriptğ‘†ğ´\mbox{tr}(\Omega^{2}_{A}{S}_{A}). The results reflect those seen in Fig. 2 in that for each pair of panels, departures from [RA(S)]âˆ—=Â±1superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´plus-or-minus1[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*}=\pm 1 are always more probable on the RA<0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 side.

We might have inferred from Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss that the cause of the different degree of importance on the RA<0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 side of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram was related to the negative strain production - positive enstrophy production state, i.e. the extension of rod-like structures. However, we see in Fig. 4 that the state where both terms are positive is also more likely to have a significant non-normal contribution to [RA(S)]âˆ—superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*} than is the case on the RA>0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 side. That it is the strain production that is preferentially influenced by non-local effects is shown by comparing the results for [RA(S)]âˆ—superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptRğ‘†ğ´[\mbox{R}^{(S)}_{A}]^{*} with those for [tr(Î©A2ğ–²A]âˆ—[\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{A}\mathsf{S}_{A}]^{*} in Fig. 5, where a large proportion of the values are at [tr(Î©A2ğ–²A]âˆ—=1[\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{A}\mathsf{S}_{A}]^{*}=1. The exceptions to this are regions 1 and 5, where the two states with positive strain production are particularly prone to non-normal interactions. This bias in favour of non-normal interactions for strain production is expected based on the pressure Hessian appearing in the dynamic equation for total strain, but not enstrophy. Hence, it is an indirect mechanism that leads to an impact of non-normality on enstrophy production. For example, we see from Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss that negative strain production and enstrophy production is particularly prevalent in region 1. Hence, dissipation by the compression of rod-like turbulent structures (Tsinober, 2001) in this region, itself affected significantly by non-normality for strain production (Fig. 4) provides a means to induce non-normal effects on the enstrophy production.

IV.4 The four production terms

The probability curves for our four production terms are given in Fig. 6 conditioned on both the sign of the term and the regions of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram. As explained in section II.3, sgnâ€‹(RB(S))=sgnâ€‹(RA)sgnsuperscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†sgnsubscriptRğ´\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)})=\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{A}) and sgnâ€‹(trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B))=âˆ’sgnâ€‹(RA)sgntrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµsgnsubscriptRğ´\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}))=-\mbox{sgn}(\mbox{R}_{A}), while trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)=0trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµ0\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B})=0 beneath the discriminant function (regions 4 and 6). Thus, the basic properties of these terms is known from our formulation.

While QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 is a useful visualization tool, it is of less obvious physical significance than Î”L>0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}>0. However, it is fairly clear from Fig. 6 that apart from the obvious difference that there is no curve for trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) where Î”L<0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}<0, the other curves exhibit a clearer difference between positive and negative QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A} states than positive and negative Î”LsubscriptÎ”ğ¿\Delta_{L} states. For example, in regions 5 and 6 we see there is very little difference in the distribution functions for RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} and RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}, while there is a small decrease in the probability of negative values for trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}) as we move from region 5 to region 6. Hence, the change in the nature of the balance between strain production and enstrophy production and, thus, RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A} as a flow parcel moves from region 5 to region 6 is driven almost entirely by the existence of a negative contribution from trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) in region 5 and its absence in region 6. Otherwise, we see that the positive and negative values for RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} approximately cancel while the interaction term is biased towards positive values. Thus, we may simplify the strain production and enstrophy production balance in region 6 to being about positive strain production and positive stretching of non-normality by the normal strain tensor. Region 5 has the same terms acting with similar strength, with an additional negative contribution by the enstrophy production term. In regions 3 and 4 we see something close to the mirror image of the behaviour in regions 5 and 6 for the two normal terms, but with the distributions for the non-normal and interaction terms similar to those in regions 5 and 6. However, RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} favours positive values more strongly in regions 3 and 4 than in regions 5 and 6, while trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}) is less biased towards positive values, particularly in region 4.

Regions 1 and 2 have qualitatively different properties to the other cases:

  • â€¢

    The magnitude of the values for RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} is drastically reduced on average in both regions 1 and 2;

  • â€¢

    The magnitude of the values for trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) increases greatly on average in both regions 1 and 2;

  • â€¢

    In region 1, it is negative values for the interaction term, trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}), that are more probable, the only region in the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram where this is the case. The positive values are also reduced in magnitude compared to other regions;

  • â€¢

    In region 1 we see positive contributions from RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} with magnitudes exceeding all other terms. This is the only region where this is the case and means that where QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, RA>0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 states are driven by both positive non-normality and negative normal enstrophy production;

  • â€¢

    In region 2, there is an increase in the bias towards positive values for both RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} and trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}), although the magnitude of these positive contributions is still dominated by normal enstrophy production, meaning that where QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, RA<0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 states are driven by this positive enstrophy production.

It was suggested in the previous subsection that in region 1, compression of vortex tubes would be a means by which non-normal strain production and enstrophy production is significant when both strain production and enstrophy production are negative. How this arises is explained by these features of region 1. Because normal strain production is positive, its eigenvalues can only lead to disc-like structures in this region. Hence, for rod-like structures to develop, the combined negative effect of the non-normal and interaction term must be sufficient to result in RA(S)<0superscriptsubscriptRğ´ğ‘†0\mbox{R}_{A}^{(S)}<0, and the frequency of negative values for the interaction term has already been commented on, and appears to be driving such occurrences. This is confirmed below when we look at the joint properties of these terms, although the extent of this effect is mediated by the positive values for the non-normal term. Given that trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) is negative and large in magnitude, compression of these tubes that result from non-normal effects is readily facilitated.

IV.5 Joint behaviour of the production terms

Further information on the structure of the production terms can be gleaned from their joint behaviours and we show RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} against the combined behaviour of the non-normal and interaction terms (Fig. 7), trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}) against the combined behaviour of the non-normal and interaction terms (Fig. 8), and disaggregate the latter terms into RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} and trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}), respectively (Fig. 9). Each panel in these three figures displays the results for each region of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram as a difference from the overall joint PDF for all regions combined, with darker contours a sink for that region of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram, and lighter contours an excess. The logarithmic nature of the bins used to generate the PDFs results in a series of â€œbutterflyâ€ plots of varying nature.

In Fig. 7, the region that most clearly violates the anticipated symmetry is region 1, where the excess is essentially at RB(S)=0superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†0\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}=0, with the bias in the non-normal and interaction terms towards negative values, as anticipated in the previous section. Where RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} has larger positive values, in the bottom-right region of this panel, RC(S)+trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}+\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}) is also strongly negative, counteracting any tendency from the eigenvalues to drive positive strain production. In Fig. 8 we see that this negative bias in RC(S)+trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}+\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}) is strongly correlated with the negative values for normal enstrophy production. We can determine which of the non-normal and interation terms are driving these negative values from Fig. 9, where we note it is the interaction term that, as already anticipated in the previous section, has a very strong bias to negative values. The non-normal term is very important to the production in region 1, but exhibits both strongly negative and positive contributions with a very weak correlation to the interaction term. To quantify these statements, we determine the cases that lie in region 1 and where trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)<0trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ0\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B})<0 and then we calculate the mean difference in the absolute production quantities. We find that

  • â€¢

    |trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)|âˆ’|RC(S)|Â¯=0.027Â¯trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµsuperscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†0.027\overline{|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B})|-|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|}=0.027;

  • â€¢

    |trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)|âˆ’|trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)|Â¯=0.027Â¯trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµtrsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ0.027\overline{|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B})|-|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B})|}=0.027;

  • â€¢

    |RB(S)|âˆ’|RC(S)|Â¯=âˆ’0.006Â¯superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†0.006\overline{|\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}|-|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|}=-0.006; and,

  • â€¢

    |RB(S)|âˆ’|trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)|Â¯=âˆ’0.005Â¯superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµ0.005\overline{|\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)}|-|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B})|}=-0.005.

That is, the normal enstrophy production is greater in magnitude on average than either the non-normal or interaction terms, both of which are greater in magnitude than the normal strain production when the interaction term is negative, as may be inferred from Fig. 6.

With the exception of region 1, the butterfly plots in Fig. 7 exhibit a general symmetry with the combined term strongly biased towards positive values and the sign of RB(S)superscriptsubscriptRğµğ‘†\mbox{R}_{B}^{(S)} given by physical constraints, resulting in a positive correlation between the terms on the right-hand side and a negative correlation on the left-hand side. This explains why strain production is highest around the Vieillefosse tail (regions 5 and 6). The results in Fig. 8 exhibit strong correlations in all four legitimate regions with the sign of this correlation, opposite in sense to that in Fig. 7 because of the opposite sign for trâ€‹(Î©B2â€‹ğ–²B)trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}). Clearly, region 1 is the unusual case again, with a strong positive correlation in the negative-negative part of this panel. It is also the case that although region 3 exhibits a strong positive correlation in the positive-positive part of the panel, there is a deficit for large values of normal enstrophy production, as can be inferred from the weak marginal distribution for this term in Fig. 6. The consequence of this is that for positive values of normal enstrophy production, the combined effect of the non-normal and interaction terms outweighs that of the normal term in region 3. An examination of the relevant panel in Fig. 9 shows that, in contrast to region 1, it is RC(S)superscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)} that drives this behaviour, which is not obvious from the marginal distributions in Fig. 6.

Given the highly structured nature of the normal terms, the joint distribution function for the non-normal and interaction terms produces a rather more unique signature in each region than is seen in Figs. 7 and 8. This is summarized in the textual descriptions in Fig. 9, where region 1 is the only region where the net average effect of these two terms is negative. We also see that the interaction term tends to dominate the non-normal contribution on the positive RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A} side of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram, with the non-normal term dominant on the negative side.

Rather than merely looking at the location of the areas of excess as is summarized in the text boxes in Fig. 9, we also looked at which term tends to dominate in each of these areas. We extracted the major excess areas for each region in Fig. 9 and determined the mean of the difference of the absolute values, |trâ€‹(Î©C2â€‹ğ–²B)|âˆ’|RC(S)|Â¯Â¯trsubscriptsuperscriptsans-serif-Î©2ğ¶subscriptğ–²ğµsuperscriptsubscriptRğ¶ğ‘†\overline{|\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B})|-|\mbox{R}_{C}^{(S)}|}, in each case. These values are given in Table LABEL:table.prod_C_interact. Thus, we can see that the non-normal term is dynamically important in region 1, as has already been reported and is seen in Fig. 6, but the interaction term is more significant both because the sign of the excess areas is where tr(Î©C2ğ–²B<0\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{\Omega}^{2}_{C}\mathsf{S}_{B}<0 and because there is a bias towards the case where both terms are negative (55:45). In contrast, in region 2, we see that the dominant area of excess is where both terms are positive, but that in this region, the interaction term is clearly dominant. In region 3 we see that the strength of the positive net effect comes from a dominant interaction term where both terms are positive, and the magnitude of the non-normal term exceeding that for the interaction term on average where the former is positive and the latter is negative. This latter situation is what also drives the weak positive net behaviour in region 4, while in regions 5 and 6 it is that the interaction term is positive and much greater in magnitude on average than the non-normal term irrespective of the sign for the latter.

IV.6 The square of the vortex stretching term

As described in (40), we decomposed the nonlinear vortex stretching term, V2superscriptğ‘‰2V^{2}, into four component terms (one purely normal term, ğ–µBâ€‹B=Î©Bâ€‹ğ–²B+ğ–²Bâ€‹Î©Bsubscriptğ–µğµğµsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµsubscriptğ–²ğµsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ\mathsf{V}_{BB}=\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}\mathsf{S}_{B}+\mathsf{S}_{B}\mathsf{\Omega}_{B}, a purely non-normal term, ğ–µCâ€‹Csubscriptğ–µğ¶ğ¶\mathsf{V}_{CC}, and two interaction terms, ğ–µBâ€‹Csubscriptğ–µğµğ¶\mathsf{V}_{BC} and ğ–µCâ€‹Bsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğµ\mathsf{V}_{CB}). In addition, we defined Vaâ€‹bâ€‹ssubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ V_{abs} to highlight that the products of the interaction terms with the non-normal term can be negative. In Fig. 10a we show the full distribution for V2/Vaâ€‹bâ€‹ssuperscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ V^{2}/V_{abs} on a log10subscriptlog10\mbox{log}_{10} scale and some properties of the cumulative distribution function for this term are listed in Table LABEL:table.V2. The two product terms are shown in Fig. 10g and Fig. 10h and the values for the fifth percentile of the distribution (in Table LABEL:table.V2) highlight that these product terms have a greater effect on the vortex stretching where QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 and is least important near the Vieillefosse tail, consistent with earlier results. Given that Î©Bsubscriptsans-serif-Î©ğµ\mathsf{\Omega}_{B} does not exist beneath the discriminant function, trâ€‹(ğ–µCâ€‹Bâ€‹ğ–µCâ€‹C)trsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğµsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğ¶\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{CB}\mathsf{V}_{CC}) will increase in magnitude with QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A} as is shown in Fig. 10h (with very little difference as a function of RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A}). This means that it is the high QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A} regions that show the greater effect of the two product terms in Fig. 10a and Table LABEL:table.V2.

The probability curves for trâ€‹(ğ–µCâ€‹B2)/Vaâ€‹bâ€‹strsuperscriptsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğµ2subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ \mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{CB}^{2})/V_{abs} in regions 1 and 2 have medians of [trâ€‹(ğ–µCâ€‹B2)/Vaâ€‹bâ€‹s]50=0.33subscriptdelimited-[]trsuperscriptsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğµ2subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ 500.33[\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{CB}^{2})/V_{abs}]_{50}=0.33 in region 1 and [trâ€‹(ğ–µCâ€‹B2)/Vaâ€‹bâ€‹s]50=0.235subscriptdelimited-[]trsuperscriptsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğµ2subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ 500.235[\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{CB}^{2})/V_{abs}]_{50}=0.235 in region 2, this difference being the primary way in which the greater emphasis on the normal stretching vector in region 2 is accommodated for when considering the other terms.

In summary, and in common with the analysis of the production terms, analysis of vortex stretching has shown the dynamical importance of the interaction between normal and non-normal terms, particularly below the discriminant function where the non-normal term remains small and the normal term is undefined as a consequence of the absence of a normal rotation tensor in this region. The negative skewness to the distribution for trâ€‹(ğ–µCâ€‹Bâ€‹ğ–µCâ€‹C)trsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğµsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğ¶\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{CB}\mathsf{V}_{CC}) in regions 1 and 2, in particular, means that for QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, the value for V2superscriptğ‘‰2V^{2} is less effectively determined by the sum of the squared terms, i.e. trâ€‹(ğ–µBâ€‹B2+ğ–µBâ€‹C2+ğ–µCâ€‹B2+ğ–µCâ€‹C2)trsuperscriptsubscriptğ–µğµğµ2superscriptsubscriptğ–µğµğ¶2superscriptsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğµ2superscriptsubscriptğ–µğ¶ğ¶2\mbox{tr}(\mathsf{V}_{BB}^{2}+\mathsf{V}_{BC}^{2}+\mathsf{V}_{CB}^{2}+\mathsf{V}_{CC}^{2}), than is the case below the discriminant function as can be seen in Table LABEL:table.V2.

V Results: The second eigenvalue of the strain rate tensor for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}

The well-known properties of the Lund and Rogers normalization, eA(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´e^{(LR)}_{A}, are shown in the upper panel of Fig. 11. The tendency for HIT to form disc-like structures is very evident. Sub-dividing the results by region of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram shows that this tendency is driven by regions 2, 5 and 6. However, given that RA>0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 in regions 1, 5 and 6, and positive strain production, âˆ’detâ€‹(ğ–²A)>0detsubscriptğ–²ğ´0-\mbox{det}(\mathsf{S}_{A})>0 means there are two positive strain eigenvalues, it is not intuitive that it is region 2, rather than region 1, where eA(Lâ€‹R)â†’1â†’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to 1. Noting in section IV.1 that only âˆ¼8%similar-toabsentpercent8\sim 8\% of data in regions 1 and 2 have ÎºQ(S)>0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0, then this property of HIT can be understood when we look at eA(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´e^{(LR)}_{A} conditioned on the sign of ÎºQ(S)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†\kappa_{Q}^{(S)} (the grey lines in Fig. 11). Where ÎºQ(S)>0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 (solid grey lines) we see the anticipated behaviour of a tendency for eA(Lâ€‹R)â†’+1â†’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to+1 in region 1 and eA(Lâ€‹R)â†’âˆ’1â†’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to-1 in region 2. Consequently, the reason for the observed behaviour is that the non-normal contribution to the strain tensor exceeds the normal part and exhibits a very different distribution to that driven by the eigenvalues. Given that it is in regions 1 and 2 that enstrophy exceeds strain and, according to the Q-criterion (Hunt etÂ al, 1988; Dubief and Delcayre, 2000), is where there is a coherence to flow motion, we can see that non-normality is crucial for the evolution of disc-like structures. Given our earlier result that contributions from ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C} do not feature in the restricted Euler formulation of the VGT dynamics, it is clear that the anistropic contributions from the pressure Hessian are extremely important for this evolution of disc-like structures. From Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss, region 2 is frequented more than twice as often as region 1 (26.5% to 11.1%), which also helps explain the strong tendency for eA(LRâ†’1e^{(LR}_{A}\to 1 seen in the top-most panel.

From Fig. 3 we can determine that ÎºQ(S)>0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 occurs for 39.4%, 68.6%, 60.6% and 82.2% of occurrences in regions 3 to 6, respectively. In Fig. 11 it is region 5 where ÎºQ(S)>0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 has the strongest tendency to produce values at eA(Lâ€‹R)=1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1, while everywhere but region 1, one finds that ÎºQ(S)<0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}<0 preferentially leads to positive values for eA(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´e^{(LR)}_{A}. The complex case is region 4, where the normal contribution to the strain is strongly dominant, but has a mode at eA(Lâ€‹R)=âˆ’0.08subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´0.08e^{(LR)}_{A}=-0.08, indicating that here the preferred state is close to isotropy (the â€œblobâ€ in the terminology of Kuo and Corrsin (1972)); any tendency to form disc-like structures is a consequence of the non-normal dominant cases in this region.

V.1 The disaggregation of the Lund and Rogers normalization of the strain rate tensor

e|A|(Lâ€‹R)=|eA(Lâ€‹R)|eB|A(Lâ€‹R)|+|eC|A(Lâ€‹R)|+|eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)||,subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğµğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´e^{(LR)}_{|A|}=\left\lvert\frac{e^{(LR)}_{A}}{|e^{(LR)}_{B|A}|+|e^{(LR)}_{C|A}|+|e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}|}\right\rvert, (56)

In this panel we see that where eB|A(Lâ€‹R)<0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğµğ´0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}<0, the combined behaviour of the non-normal and interaction terms behaves with some degree of symmetry about eC|A(Lâ€‹R)+eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)=0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´0e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=0, although with a bias towards positive values as might be expected from the global result of a tendency for eA(Lâ€‹R)â†’1â†’subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}\to 1. V.2 Results conditioned on QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} states

In order to explore these results further, we look at joint PDFs similar to Fig. 13 conditioned on the different regions of QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} space, which are shown in Fig. 15. Regarding eB|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğµğ´e^{(LR)}_{B|A}, it is regions 5 and 6 where this term generates eA(Lâ€‹R)=1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1 values as might be anticipated from the earlier analysis showing the importance of the normal tensor in this region. It is region 3 where the normal term generates eA(Lâ€‹R)=âˆ’1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}=-1 on its own, and where the strong frontier shows that all terms combine to give this result. Hence, when eB|A(Lâ€‹R)=0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğµğ´0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=0, there is a strong positive bias for the non-normal and interaction term that drives a eA(Lâ€‹R)=1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1 response. Region 5 has a concentration of values along and near to the frontier in the positive quadrant where the terms interact to give eA(Lâ€‹R)=1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}=1, while region 4 can lead to eA(Lâ€‹R)=âˆ’1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}=-1, but the dominant behaviour is for eB|A(Lâ€‹R)=0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğµğ´0e^{(LR)}_{B|A}=0 and for positive values to emerge on average because of the strong positive bias for eC|A(Lâ€‹R)+eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´e^{(LR)}_{C|A}+e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}. Another final means to generate eA(Lâ€‹R)=âˆ’1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{A}=-1 is from the combined effect of the non-normal and interaction terms in regions 1 and 2 when the normal term is expressed most weakly.

The structure of the ordinate in Fig. 15 is unpacked in Fig. 16 where we can again see a great variation in structure of the joint PDFs. Region 1 is particularly interesting as the distributions exhibits a ridge with a 90Â°bend so that in addition to a global maximum at the origin, we see that eC|A(Lâ€‹R)=+1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´1e^{(LR)}_{C|A}=+1 and eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)=âˆ’1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´1e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=-1 have high probability. The complex behaviour is explained in Fig. 17, where the joint PDFs for eC|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´e^{(LR)}_{C|A} and eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} in regions 1 and 2 are further conditioned on the sign for ÎºQ(S)superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}. This is reflected by the PDFs in regions 1 and 2 exhibiting little variance on the eC|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´e^{(LR)}_{C|A} axis and with a typical value for eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} with a sign opposite to that for RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A}. However, when ÎºQ(S)<0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}<0 (top row of panels), there is a dominance of the interaction term in region 2 and the non-normal term in region 1. Hence, in region 2, the strong tendency for the eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} distribution to dominate and to peak close to +1 for ÎºQ(S)>0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0 is reinforced by the situation for the ÎºQ(S)<0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}<0 case. In contrast, the two states act orthogonally in region 1, giving the 90Â°bend to the joint PDF, with the maximum along eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)=0,eC|A(Lâ€‹R)>0formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´0e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A}=0,e^{(LR)}_{C|A}>0 due to the mere âˆ¼8%similar-toabsentpercent8\sim 8\% of cases where ÎºQ(S)>0superscriptsubscriptğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘†0\kappa_{Q}^{(S)}>0.

The QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram exhibits a concentration of values in regions 2 and 6 as shown in Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss. We have already seen in Fig. 15 that the tendency to disc-like structures in region 6 is driven firstly by eB|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğµğ´e^{(LR)}_{B|A} and then by the combined interaction of all terms. Figure 15 shows that region 2 also contributes effectively to this tendency to form disc-like structures, but is about eC,B|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…ğ¶conditionalğµğ´e^{(LR)}_{C,B|A} solely, or its interaction with eC|A(Lâ€‹R)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘’ğ¿ğ‘…conditionalğ¶ğ´e^{(LR)}_{C|A} rather than the normal term.

In summary, there is a bias towards RA>0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}>0 states in the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram as shown in Table LABEL:table.Q_wws_sss and our approach highlights that the organization of the straining part of the normal tensor is constrained to be greater or equal to zero on this half of the diagram. However, this bias (54.6:45.4) is insufficient to explain the strong tendency to form disc-like structures. Our decomposition shows that this state emerges in a variety of different ways in different parts of QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} space as summarized in Table LABEL:table.LRsummary, and that the overall behaviour is dominated by the normal and interaction terms, with the non-normal term making, on average a weak contribution. However, in region 1, the non-normal term is of particular importance. It is also clear from both 15 and LABEL:fig.eLRB_C1_C2_regions that our decomposition of this space into six regions is justified; while the topological analysis of this space prioritizes positive and negative values for Î”LsubscriptÎ”ğ¿\Delta_{L} over the sign of QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}, our results for the QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 regions in particular are very different in nature.

VI Results: Vorticity vector and strain eigenvector alignments

VI.1 The existing relations for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}

As is well known, and is shown in Fig. 18, ğAsubscriptğğ´\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A} is typically most strongly aligned with ğ2Asubscriptsuperscriptğğ´2\mathbf{e}^{A}_{2}. If we extract the cases where Î¸iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 (i.e. Â±10âˆ˜plus-or-minussuperscript10\pm 10^{\circ}), we obtain the results shown in Fig. 19. What is particularly notable in this figure is the high proportion of Î¸iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 occurrences in regions 2 and 6 (âˆ¼36%similar-toabsentpercent36\sim 36\% in both cases), the two regions that HIT occupies preferentially relative to random, synthetic tensors with appropriate bounds on their non-normality (Keylock, 2017). This relative occupancy is 1.4 times, and 1.2 times higher than is the case for all tensors (without conditioning on region of occurrence) as shown in Fig. 19. Overall, 81% of cases where Î¸iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 were for Î¸2A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´2\theta^{A,A}_{2}, with 16% for Î¸1A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{1}, and the propensity for alignment with Î¸1A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{1} and Î¸3A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´3\theta^{A,A}_{3} dictated by the sign of RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A} where Î”L>0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}>0 and dominated by Î¸1A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{1} below the discriminant function. Region 3 is the only part of the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} diagram where Î¸2A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´2\theta^{A,A}_{2} alignments are secondary.

VI.2 Vorticity-vorticity alignments

The decomposition into components derived from ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B} and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C} provides insights into the Î¸iA,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignments discussed above. First, we examine the mutual vorticity vector alignments, above the discriminant function (because below it, Î¾A,C=1superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶1\xi^{A,C}=1 everywhere). Figure 20 shows that immediately above the discriminant function, a strong tendency for the vorticity vector for Î¾A,Câ†’1â†’superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶1\xi^{A,C}\to 1 is retained. However, when QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 this is a weaker effect, with a stronger alignment for Î¾A,Bsuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğµ\xi^{A,B}. The accompanying curves for Î¾B,Csuperscriptğœ‰ğµğ¶\xi^{B,C} show that there is very limited strong alignment between ğBsuperscriptğğµ\boldsymbol{\omega}^{B} and ğCsuperscriptğğ¶\boldsymbol{\omega}^{C}, meaning there are two distinct sets of vorticity vectors in the positive QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A} regions depending on these alignments.

When we condition these distributions on Î¸iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 (i.e. Â±10âˆ˜plus-or-minussuperscript10\pm 10^{\circ}) and then seek cases where Î¾A,B>0.985superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğµ0.985\xi^{A,B}>0.985 and Î¾A,C>0.985superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶0.985\xi^{A,C}>0.985, we obtain the results seen in Fig. 21. The percentages in each panel indicate the efficiency by which strong Î¸iA,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignments lead to strong Î¾A,Bsuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğµ\xi^{A,B} or Î¾A,Csuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶\xi^{A,C} alignments. Given that such values are at 100% for Î¾A,Csuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶\xi^{A,C} where Î”L<0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}<0, there is a clear decrease in this propensity as QAsubscriptQğ´\mbox{Q}_{A} increases. However, there is a major difference between region 5, which adjoins the Vieillefosse tail, and region 3, with the former approximately twice as effective at retaining strong alignments between the vorticity vectors for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}.

It is clear from Fig. 20 that in regions 3 and 5, Î¾A,Csuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶\xi^{A,C} dominates the strong alignments and this is clearly the case in Fig. 21, not only for where Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985, but also for where Î¸1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985 in region 3. However, an important contrast between Fig. 21 and Fig. 19 can be detected in region 3 in that the number of significant alignments for Î¾A,Bsuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğµ\xi^{A,B} and Î¾A,Csuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶\xi^{A,C} is far fewer for cases where Î¸1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985, despite these cases being more numerous in Fig. 19. Hence, the observed Î¸1A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{1} alignments in region 3, and the low percentages in regions 1 and 2 show that mutual vorticity alignment is a less important explanation for the Î¸iA,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignments than is the case in regions 4, 5, and 6.

In regions 1 and 2 of Fig. 21 we see that any degree of excess for Î¸2A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´2\theta^{A,A}_{2} compared to Î¸1A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{1} (region 2) or Î¸3A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´3\theta^{A,A}_{3} (region 1) is much less than is seen in Fig. 19 - the opposite scenario to region 3. It is also the case that Î¾A,Bsuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğµ\xi^{A,B} alignments completely dominate for Î¸1A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{1} and Î¸3A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´3\theta^{A,A}_{3} alignments. Thus, while mutual vorticity alignments are relatively rare where QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0, there is a clear difference regarding the types of alignments structures that occur: alignment between ğAsubscriptğğ´\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A} and the largest or smallest strain eigenvector retains structure between ğAsubscriptğğ´\boldsymbol{\omega}_{A} and ğBsubscriptğğµ\boldsymbol{\omega}_{B} - it is a consequence of local interactions. In contrast, while local interactions are still relevant for alignments with the intermediate strain eigenvector, it is here than non-local interactions, as signified by Î¾A,Csuperscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶\xi^{A,C} alignments, are most important.

VI.3 Vorticity and strain alignments for ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B} and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}

Figure 22 shows the distributions for Î¸iB,Bsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğµğµ\theta_{i}^{B,B}, Î¸iB,Csuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğµğ¶\theta_{i}^{B,C}, Î¸iC,Bsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ¶ğµ\theta_{i}^{C,B}, and Î¸iC,Csuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ¶ğ¶\theta_{i}^{C,C}, and there are several points of interest:

  • â€¢

    Strong alignments for particular terms are more probable where RA>0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}>0;

  • â€¢

    Because of the structure of ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B}, for Î”L>0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}>0, Î¸1B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} drives the alignments for RA<0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 and Î¸3B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ3\theta^{B,B}_{3} where RA>0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}>0;

  • â€¢

    The Î¸2C,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğ¶2\theta^{C,C}_{2} alignment is so dominant in regions 4 and 6 that probabilities are shown on a logarithmic axis;

  • â€¢

    Strong alignments for Î¸2C,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğ¶2\theta^{C,C}_{2} and Î¸1C,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğµ1\theta^{C,B}_{1} for Î”L<0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}<0 are replaced by strong alignments for either Î¸1B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} or Î¸3B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ3\theta^{B,B}_{3}, and also Î¸2C,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğ¶2\theta^{C,C}_{2} where Î”L>0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}>0 and QA<0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}<0 and then a clear dominance for Î¸1B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} or Î¸3B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ3\theta^{B,B}_{3} where QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0;

  • â€¢

    Where they are defined, Î¸1B,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğ¶1\theta^{B,C}_{1} and Î¸3B,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğ¶3\theta^{B,C}_{3} have clear maxima at Â±45âˆ˜plus-or-minussuperscript45\pm 45^{\circ}; if this is rather strictly the case as happens in region 5, then the mode for Î¸2B,Câ†’0â†’subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğ¶20\theta^{B,C}_{2}\to 0, while in the other regions the mode for Î¸2B,Câ†’1â†’subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğ¶21\theta^{B,C}_{2}\to 1;
