Results regarding strong alignments for these cases conditioned on strong alignments for Î¸iA,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–\theta^{A,A}_{i} are given in Fig. 23, where the numbers in each panel are the sum of the values in that panel and the percentages relate directly to those in Fig. 19: the sum of the percentages in a row of Fig. 23 equals the percentages in Fig. 19, with the exception of regions 4 and 6, where the very small contributions from strong Î¸3A,Asuperscriptsubscriptğœƒ3ğ´ğ´\theta_{3}^{A,A} alignments have been excluded. It is notable that the sum of the values in the panels for regions 4 to 6 tend to exceed 1.0. That is, for a given tensor more than one vorticity vector - strain eigenvector pair is strongly aligned. It is also the case that in these regions, nearly all tensors exhibit a strong alignment for Î¸2C,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğ¶2\theta^{C,C}_{2} when Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985. Given that Î¾A,C=1superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶1\xi^{A,C}=1 for regions 4 and 6 and the majority of alignments arise for Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985, we have a physical explanation for the second eigenvector alignment here: it is driven by non-normal vorticity alignment, coupled to a strong alignment between the second eigenvector of the non-normal strain tensor and the second eigenvector for ğ–²Asubscriptğ–²ğ´\mathsf{S}_{A} with co-alignment with the second eigenvector for ğ–²Bsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mathsf{S}_{B} also arising in a number of cases. Thus, while the analysis in the previous sections has highlighted the weak effects of non-normality in region 6, in particular, regarding strain tensor effects, because there is no normal rotation tensor in this region, non-normality plays a critical part in enstrophy production because Î¾A,C=1superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶1\xi^{A,C}=1.

In regions 1 and 2, there are not only fewer cases where Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 compared to Î¸3A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´30.985\theta^{A,A}_{3}>0.985 (region 1) and Î¸1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985 (region 2), but the conversion rate of an Î¸iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 alignment to one for another vorticity vector - strain eigenvector is more efficient for Î¸1A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{1} and Î¸3A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´3\theta^{A,A}_{3} at 37% and 50%, respectively, compared to 19% for Î¸2A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´2\theta^{A,A}_{2}. For example, in region 2, 0.11Ã—30.9=3.40.1130.93.40.11\times 30.9=3.4% for Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 is less than double 0.37Ã—5.2=1.90.375.21.90.37\times 5.2=1.9% for Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985, despite the six times higher proportion of Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 instances. For Î¸1A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{1} and Î¸3A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´3\theta^{A,A}_{3}, the dominant alignment is for Î¸iB,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµğ‘–\theta^{B,B}_{i}, with the value for iğ‘–i equating to that in the Î¸iA,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignment. Similar alignments are also important where Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 in regions 1 and 2. Thus, normal vorticity-strain interactions generated by local effects are the most important where QA>0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}>0 and the overall result of Î¸2A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´2\theta^{A,A}_{2} dominating the alignment structure is really (in terms of direct effects) a consequence of the high values for Î¸2C,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğ¶2\theta^{C,C}_{2} in region 6 where normal vorticity does not exist.

The only real role played by the interaction terms are the Î¸1C,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğµ1\theta^{C,B}_{1} alignments seen in regions 3, 4, and 6 where Î¸1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985 . From the bottom row of Fig. 22 it can be seen that while the mode for this curve lies close to 1, the peak is an order of magnitude smaller than that for Î¸2C,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğ¶2\theta^{C,C}_{2} and it is clear that when Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 this term is of minor importance. Hence, the non-normal vorticity vector aligning with the leading strain eigenvector for ğ–²Bsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mathsf{S}_{B} is important for Î¸1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985, although that the sums of the alignments in regions 4 and 6 are much greater than 1 shows that there is a co-alignment between the first eigenvector of ğ–²Bsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mathsf{S}_{B} and the second for ğ–²Csubscriptğ–²ğ¶\mathsf{S}_{C} in these regions. Clearly, therefore, the co-alignment between ğ1Bsubscriptsuperscriptğğµ1\mathbf{e}^{B}_{1} and ğ1Asubscriptsuperscriptğğ´1\mathbf{e}^{A}_{1} must be stronger than that for ğ2Csubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} and ğ2Asubscriptsuperscriptğğ´2\mathbf{e}^{A}_{2} to produce this result.

VI.4 Strain-strain eigenvector alignments

We can observe clear structure in the mutual strain alignments, Ï•i,jA,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ´ğµ\phi_{i,j}^{A,B}, Ï•i,jA,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ´ğ¶\phi_{i,j}^{A,C}, and Ï•i,jB,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—ğµğ¶\phi_{i,j}^{B,C}, which are summarized by the modes for each distribution function in Fig. 24. In essence, regions 1 and 2 exhibit a perfect alignment between ğiAsubscriptsuperscriptğğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{A}_{i} and ğiCsubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶ğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{C}_{i}, while for regions 4 and 6 there is a close to perfect alignment between ğiAsubscriptsuperscriptğğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{A}_{i} and ğiBsubscriptsuperscriptğğµğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{B}_{i}, that is particularly the case for the latter. In region 3 we see a mutual alignment for Ï•3,3A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•33ğ´ğ¶\phi_{3,3}^{A,C}, but with the other two eigenvectors aligning with each other such that different tensors have strong Ï•1,1A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•11ğ´ğ¶\phi_{1,1}^{A,C}, Ï•1,2A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•12ğ´ğ¶\phi_{1,2}^{A,C}, Ï•2,1A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•21ğ´ğ¶\phi_{2,1}^{A,C} and Ï•2,2A,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•22ğ´ğ¶\phi_{2,2}^{A,C} alignments. This behaviour is inverted in the Ï•i,jA,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ´ğµ\phi_{i,j}^{A,B} results, with a strong alignment for Ï•1,1A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•11ğ´ğµ\phi_{1,1}^{A,B}, and different tensors having strong Ï•2,2A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•22ğ´ğµ\phi_{2,2}^{A,B}, Ï•2,3A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•23ğ´ğµ\phi_{2,3}^{A,B}, Ï•3,2A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•32ğ´ğµ\phi_{3,2}^{A,B} and Ï•3,3A,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•33ğ´ğµ\phi_{3,3}^{A,B} alignments. Region 5 might be expected to be the mirror image of region 3 and this is approximately the case for the Ï•i,jA,Bsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ´ğµ\phi_{i,j}^{A,B} results. However, the Ï•i,jA,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ´ğ¶\phi_{i,j}^{A,C} results are much more similar to those for regions 1 and 2 with alignments at Ï•i=jA,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ´ğ¶\phi_{i=j}^{A,C}.

The consequences of these alignments between the ğiAsubscriptsuperscriptğğ´ğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{A}_{i} and ğiBsubscriptsuperscriptğğµğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{B}_{i} and ğjCsubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶ğ‘—\mathbf{e}^{C}_{j} strain tensors for the mutual relation between the ğiBsubscriptsuperscriptğğµğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{B}_{i} and ğjCsubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶ğ‘—\mathbf{e}^{C}_{j} is shown in the bottom panel of Fig. 24. In region 4, Ï•1,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•12ğµğ¶\phi_{1,2}^{B,C} is aligned well with the other ğjCsubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶ğ‘—\mathbf{e}^{C}_{j} (iâˆˆ{1,3}ğ‘–13i\in\{1,3\}) at 45âˆ˜superscript4545^{\circ} to the ğiBsubscriptsuperscriptğğµğ‘–\mathbf{e}^{B}_{i}. A similar result exists for the other regions where RA<0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}<0 (regions 2 and 3), although it is less coherent, with a weaker attraction to 45âˆ˜superscript4545^{\circ} and (small) residual orientations for Ï•2,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•22ğµğ¶\phi_{2,2}^{B,C} and Ï•3,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•32ğµğ¶\phi_{3,2}^{B,C}. Region 1 is, in turn, similar to these regions with the exception that, as a consequence of RA>0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}>0, the dominant alignment is Ï•3,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•32ğµğ¶\phi_{3,2}^{B,C} not Ï•1,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•12ğµğ¶\phi_{1,2}^{B,C}. Regions 5 and 6 are very similar to one another: As with region 4, a mode at 45âˆ˜superscript4545^{\circ} is strongly expressed, but in contrast, rather than just a strong alignment for Ï•1,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•12ğµğ¶\phi_{1,2}^{B,C}, two discrete sets of points exist with strong alignments for both Ï•1,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•12ğµğ¶\phi_{1,2}^{B,C} and Ï•2,2B,Csuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•22ğµğ¶\phi_{2,2}^{B,C}.

Similar results to these but conditioned on Î¸iA,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–\theta^{A,A}_{i} alignments are shown in Fig. 25. In terms of the Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 cases in the central column our first result is that the mutual strain alignments are much more important in regions 1 and 2 (0.54 and 0.58 of 6.6% and 30.9%) than the vorticity-strain alignments in Fig. 23 (0.19 and 0.11 of 6.6% and 30.9%), with the opposite the case in regions 3 to 6 where QA<0subscriptQğ´0\mbox{Q}_{A}<0. Hence, we have the somewhat counterintuitive result that in enstrophy dominant regions, mutual strain alignments are of particular prominence for explaining vorticity-strain alignments. However, the reason is clearly a combination of Î¾A,C=1superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶1\xi^{A,C}=1 for Î”L<0subscriptÎ”ğ¿0\Delta_{L}<0, while vorticity-vorticity alignments are more complex in regions 1 and 2 (Fig. 20), as well as the mutual alignments for Ï•i=jA,Csubscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ï•ğ´ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘—\phi^{A,C}_{i=j} for regions 1 and 2 in Fig. 24b.

For the Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 cases we see that ğ3Bsubscriptsuperscriptğğµ3\mathbf{e}^{B}_{3} and ğ2Csubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} are aligned in region 1 and ğ1Bsubscriptsuperscriptğğµ1\mathbf{e}^{B}_{1} and ğ2Csubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} in regions 2 and 3. In regions 4 to 6, two sets of points arise with either alignments between ğ1Bsubscriptsuperscriptğğµ1\mathbf{e}^{B}_{1} and ğ2Csubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} or ğ2Bsubscriptsuperscriptğğµ2\mathbf{e}^{B}_{2} and ğ2Csubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2}. Such results for Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 are consistent with the patterns seen in Fig. 24c, with the exception of region 4. However, in regions 3 to 6 in particular, mutual strain alignments are more clearly expressed for the Î¸1A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´10.985\theta^{A,A}_{1}>0.985 and Î¸3A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´30.985\theta^{A,A}_{3}>0.985 cases, and here the results are readily explained by the sign of RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A}, as they are for the Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 situation for regions 1 and 2: where RA>0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}>0, ğ3Bsubscriptsuperscriptğğµ3\mathbf{e}^{B}_{3} and ğ2Csubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} are aligned; while, where RA<0subscriptRğ´0\mbox{R}_{A}<0, ğ1Bsubscriptsuperscriptğğµ1\mathbf{e}^{B}_{1} and ğ2Csubscriptsuperscriptğğ¶2\mathbf{e}^{C}_{2} are aligned.

VI.5 Summary

A summary of the results in this section regarding the nature of the Î¸2A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´2\theta^{A,A}_{2} alignment, in particular, is provided in Fig. 26. As noted in the caption for this figure, the description for each region concerns only one alignment if it much more frequent than the next most common, i.e. Î¸2A,Aâ‰«Î¸1A,Amuch-greater-thansubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´2subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´1\theta^{A,A}_{2}\gg\theta^{A,A}_{1}, while both are described if the difference in relative frequencies is more minor, as arises in regions 3 and 4. All told 81% of the Î¸iA,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´ğ‘–0.985\theta^{A,A}_{i}>0.985 alignments were for Î¸2A,Asubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´2\theta^{A,A}_{2}, with, in turn, 38% and 37% of these instances occuring in regions 2 and 6, respectively. Thus, focusing on these two regions in the first instance:

  • â€¢

    Region 2 - All three strain eigenvectors for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} are aligned very closely with those with the same order for ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}. There is then two ways that the Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985 state is generated: a direct route resulting from this strain eigenvector state combined with the Î¸2C,Csubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğ¶2\theta^{C,C}_{2} alignment; and, an indirect route where the Î¸1B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} alignment and the Ï•i=jA,C=1subscriptsuperscriptitalic-Ï•ğ´ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘—1\phi^{A,C}_{i=j}=1 state, combines with the alignment between the leading eigenvector for ğ–²Bsubscriptğ–²ğµ\mathsf{S}_{B} and the intermediate eigenvector for ğ–²Csubscriptğ–²ğ¶\mathsf{S}_{C}. It should be noted that at the end of section IV.2 it was suggested based on the results shown in Fig. 3 that, in effect, Î¸1B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ1\theta^{B,B}_{1} would be an important alignment in region 2 (and Î¸3B,Bsubscriptsuperscriptğœƒğµğµ3\theta^{B,B}_{3} in region 1), which has been shown in the subsequent analysis;

  • â€¢

VII Conclusion

A radical interpretation of our approach to the additive decomposition of the velocity gradient tensor, ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} into normal and non-normal tensors, ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B} and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}, is to state that while strain production takes place everywhere, enstrophy production does not occur beneath the discriminant function. Instead, from Table LABEL:table.terms, we have either the self-amplification of non-normality, or the normal straining of non-normality acting as a source of enstrophy production beneath the discriminant function. However, that these terms also act as an equal source for strain production means that in regions 4 and 6, (beneath the discriminant function) the third invariant for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} (RAsubscriptRğ´\mbox{R}_{A} in our notation and simply R conventionally) is just the strain production for ğ–¡ğ–¡\mathsf{B}.

As there is no normal rotation tensor in these regions, there is a perfect alignment between the vorticity vectors for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A} and ğ–¢ğ–¢\mathsf{C}, i.e. Î¾A,C=1superscriptğœ‰ğ´ğ¶1\xi^{A,C}=1. From Fig. 23 we see that when Î¸2A,A>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ´ğ´20.985\theta^{A,A}_{2}>0.985, i.e. there is a strong alignment between the vorticity vector and the eigenvector for the intermediate strain eigenvalue for ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}, there is an accompanying high frequency of occurrences where Î¸2C,C>0.985subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ¶ğ¶20.985\theta^{C,C}_{2}>0.985. The consequence of this â€œnon-normalâ€ alignment is important throughout all the QAâˆ’RAsubscriptQğ´subscriptRğ´\mbox{Q}_{A}-\mbox{R}_{A} regions, but is crucial beneath the discriminant function where non-normality is the only source for enstrophy. This, coupled to the high proportion of the time that the flow spends in region 6 explains the alignment between vorticity and the intermediate eigenvector.

The importance of the non-local, non-normal contributions to the dynamics explains the difficulty of applying eigenvalue-focused thinking to the dynamics of complex systems such a turbulence. In a set of landmark papers in the 1990s it was shown that the difficulties of treating hydrodynamic stability in terms of the instability of the eigenvalues of the linearized problem could be overcome using pseudospectra (Reddy etÂ al, 1993; Trefethen etÂ al, 1993), aspects of which characterize the tensor non-normality (Trefethen and Embree, 2005). It was something of a surprise to fluid mechanics when the first direct numerical simulations of HIT showed a preferential alignment between the vorticity vector and the eigenvector for the second eigenvalue of the strain tensor rather than the first eigenvalue (Kerr, 1985; Ashurst etÂ al, 1987). Our Schur decomposition-based approach to VGT dynamics clarifies this matter because much of the interesting dynamics resides in either the non-normal terms (the alignment between the non-normal vorticity and the second eigenvector of the non-normal straining) or is in the interaction between normal and non-normal effects (production by normal straining of the non-normal term). Clearly, these terms are not captured by the eigenvalues of ğ– ğ– \mathsf{A}, highlighting that, as with hydrodynamic stability, looking beyond the eigenvalues is crucial. The advantage of the Schur transform in this respect is that the non-normality, ğ–­ğ–­\mathsf{N} is projected into the Schur matrix where it can be treated in a similar way to the eigenvalues, Î›Î›\Lambda. Hence, we could define ğ–¡=ğ–´â€‹Î›â€‹ğ–´âˆ—ğ–¡ğ–´sans-serif-Î›superscriptğ–´\mathsf{B}=\mathsf{U}\mathsf{\Lambda}\mathsf{U}^{*} and ğ–¢=ğ–´ğ–­ğ–´âˆ—ğ–¢superscriptğ–´ğ–­ğ–´\mathsf{C}=\mathsf{U}\mathsf{N}\mathsf{U}^{*}. Thus, the rotations matrix, ğ–´ğ–´\mathsf{U} retains a unitary form irrespective of the degree of non-normality. In contrast, the eigenvalue decomposition projects the non-normality into the departure of the eigenvectors from a unitary form, making it harder to directly compare normal (local) and non-normal (non-local) effects.

It is only really along the Vieillefosse tail that normal effects, in particular, normal straining, dominate the dynamics. This helps explain the success of the restricted Euler model (Cantwell, 1992) in approximating the dynamics of the VGT, but the more complex behaviour in region 1, in particular, demonstrates the difficulty of understanding the non-local effects that predominate without considering both the eigenvalues and the non-normal contributions. This work defines a suite of quantities that can serve as a new basis for evaluting existing models for the dynamics of the VGT (Wilczek and Meneveau, 2014; Johnson and Meneveau, 2016), and perhaps for formulating new models of this type.

Appendix A Complex and real Schur transforms
